panels.description:
Memory Resident Set Size used by the Erlang VM, as measured by the OS kernel.

* [Reasoning About Memory Use](https://www.rabbitmq.com/memory-use.html)
panels.title: Memory

panels.description:
File descriptor count and limit, as reported by the operating system. The count includes network sockets and file handles.

* [Open File Handles Limit](https://www.rabbitmq.com/production-checklist.html#resource-limits-file-handle-limit)
panels.title: File descriptors

panels.description: All work happens in an Erlang process - it's the basic unit of concurrency. Think of an Erlang process as a lightweight thread. A RabbitMQ queue is an Erlang process. Same for a channel, connection, vhost or message store.
panels.title: Erlang processes

panels.description:
* [Disk Space](https://www.rabbitmq.com/production-checklist.html#resource-limits-disk-space)
* [Persistence Configuration](https://www.rabbitmq.com/persistence-conf.html)
* [Free Disk Space Alarms](https://www.rabbitmq.com/disk-alarms.html)
panels.title: Disk

panels.description:
The network sockets count and limit managed by RabbitMQ.

* [Networking and RabbitMQ](https://www.rabbitmq.com/networking.html)
* [Open File Handles Limit](https://www.rabbitmq.com/production-checklist.html#resource-limits-file-handle-limit)
panels.title: Socket descriptors
